She hopes that the purchase will help expand the sales business and generate additional income, so that she can afford sending her child to a college.

loans.use: Purchase of a freezer for a sales business

loans.name: Mastura

texts.ru: Мастура 1946 года рождения , имеет единственного сына. Она работает поваром в Детском доме. Также подрабатывает на рынке продавая коктейли и попкорн.  Ей в торговле помогает невестка. (На фото ее невестка) Она сидит пока Мастура на работе. Мастура имеет 3 внука , старшая внучка выходит скоро замуж. Она решила сделать свадебный подарок курпа –национальный матрас. Сейчас сезон прохладительных напитков и у нее бизнес идет хорошо, вот она решила увеличить свой оборот за счет получившего кредита. И от оборота хочет получить хорошую прибыль. На накопившую прибыль  она и купит тот подарок который хочет сделать своей внучке.
texts.en:
Mastura was born in 1946 and has one son. She works as a cook at the orphanage. She also sells smoothies and popcorn at a market. Her daughter-in-law helps her with the sales (the photograph shows her daughter-in-law). She fills in while Mastura is at work. Mastura has 3 grandchildren, and her oldest granddaughter is getting married soon. Mastura decided to give a kurpa, which is a traditional mattress, as a wedding gift. Now is the season for chilled beverages, and her business is going well. So she decided to increase her turnover using this loan. And she wants to make a good profit from the turnover. Mastura, then, will buy her granddaughter’s wedding present, using the resulting profit.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase turnover

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.es:
La señora Rosalina pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cajas Reales”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Chucuito, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 37 años de edad, de estado civil casada, es madre de 3 hijos.  Tiene estudios de secundaria completa y vive en la Comunidad de Chinchera, Sector San Bartolomé.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace casi 1 año, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el cual compró lanas para la elaboración de artesanías.

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 700.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de lana y tejer todo tipo de artesanías en miniatura, y también teje chompas, chalinas, gorros, etc.
 
Su mayor  deseo es estudiar y puede ayudarse vendiendo las artesanías que produce.

A ella le gusta compartir sus experiencias  con sus compañeras, le gusta la facilidad de los préstamos que ofrece Manuela Ramos.
texts.en:
Rosalina is a member of the “Cajas Reales” Communal Bank located in the Chucuito district in the province of Puno, in the department of Puno. She is married, 37 years old, and is the mother of 3 children. She has completed secondary school studies and lives in the San Bartolomé sector of the Chinchera community.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for almost 1 year. Her first loan was 500.00 PEN, which she used to buy wool to make handicrafts.

She now needs a loan of 700.00 PEN to purchase wool and sew each type of handicraft in miniature form, as well as sew sweaters, scarves, hats, etc.

Her biggest dream is to study and she can help herself by selling the handicrafts that she makes.

Rosalina likes sharing her experiences with her partners. She likes the easy access to loans that Manuela Ramos offers.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wool to make handicrafts

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en:
Dilbar has developed a successful clothing business, selling higher-quality women’s underclothes and children’s clothes. She is an experienced entrepreneur, having started her venture about eight years ago. Dilbar chose to sell women’s underclothes because she knew there would always be good demand from women desiring to replenish their wardrobe.

She tries to maximize her sales by frequently updating her product selection, and she has requested a loan to help her purchase new supplies of clothing inventory. Dilbar has proven to be a hard-working entrepreneur with integrity and we are happy to further assist with her business.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To buy new children's clothing in order to expand her range of clothes for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Yat Mao Group Loan

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat M. is the group leader of five people who are all living in Srah Trakuon village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Yat M. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. On this plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She would use the rest of the money to hire a laborer to plow the field.

Mrs. Yat M. has five children two of whom are employed in different jobs while the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Moeuk Hon, helps her in the plantation.

All the members of this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and to hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.name: Carlos Luis

texts.es: El señor Carlos C. tiene 56 años D. edad, es Casado D. oficios Artesano,  “Elaboración D. Cortes Típicos”, habita junto  a su esposa, el y su esposa se dedican al mismo oficio cuentan con dos empleados para la misma actividad, lleva 18 años D. elaborar cortes  su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje Xeatzam uno del Cantón Nimapá, del departamento D. Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda D. su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que el pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención D. comprar materia prima y D. esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones D. vida
texts.en:
Señor Carlos C. is 56 years of age, married and lives with his wife in their home in Paraje Xeatzam in the Cantón of Nimapá, Department of Totonicapán, Guatemala. He and his wife work at making Cortes Típicos, traditional Guatemalan clothing, and they also have two employees for the same. They have been doing this for 18 years. At present, their customers' demand is growing but current economic conditions have not allowed them to build up any capital. That's why they have approached Asociación ASDIR to request a loan for the purpose of buying raw materials so that they will be able to increase their sales. They are also hoping they and their family will be able to get ahead and improve their living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda is 50 years old and lives with her children in her own apartment. For more than two years she has been selling manufactured products. She is a very orderly and well-organized person and keeps a detailed record with all the data of her clients to be able to offer them her products and attend to them properly. In the future she would like to have a commercial stand where she can exhibit her products. This is Mavluda’s first loan with IMON International and she feels obliged to work with commitment and wholeheartedly with the members of her solidarity group. The total amount requested will be spent on buying manufactured products in bulk. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Gema

texts.en:
Gema V. is from the village of Sinian. She is 42 years old. Gema is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Gema owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing cargo transport services to local community members. Gema has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2002, Gema joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gema has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Gema is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Gema from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to the borrower's house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for rice production purposes

loans.name: Atuk

texts.en:
Atuk R. sells beer at a bar. She is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Atuk is 30 years old. Her husband is a peasant. She has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a lorry to carry crates of beer from the White Bull breweries to her bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Barno

texts.en: Problems and money shortages never defeated Barno, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. She is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 32 years old, married, and the loving mother of three children. For more than 6 years, Barno has operated a store where she sells women’s clothing. As a rule she travels to the neighboring town to get new garments at very cheap prices. Her store is well known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Barno hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family, especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. She promises to repay the loan with accuracy as she has done with previous loans. Be an important part of the growth of Barno’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for women in order to increase the range of her goods

loans.name: Seangneng

texts.en: Mrs. Seangneng K. lives in Troey Troeng village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables.  Her husband, Mr. Seng Kheng, helps her in the business. On this farm, Mrs. Seangneng K. faces a small problem because she does not have enough rice seeds to cultivate rice. Thus, Mrs. Seangneng K. is requesting a loan to buy rice seeds and fertilizer to support the field. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. She is a mother of six children. One of her children is a garment factory worker, four are beauticians and the youngest one attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Rhona

texts.en:
Rhona is 37 and married with seven children aged between 5 and 18 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a six-roomed house where she is staying with ten people. Rhona takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Rhona incurs transport costs to and from buying charcoal from villages of Luwero, one of the districts of central Uganda, and uses public transport to and from Luwero. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Rhona works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both wholesale and retail. She doesn’t pay monthly rent as she works from her home. Her major business challenges are the rainy season and transportation.

Rhona has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for twelve years. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for her shop. She is aspiring of seeing her business grower bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Belancille

texts.en:
Belancille is 32 years old and married with four children.  The children are between ten months and eight years old.  Belancille and her family live in Musanze, a region of Ruhengeri, in the northern province of Rwanda, which is approximately two hours' drive from the capital, Kigali.  Belancille has been successfully selling foodstuffs (Irish potatoes) for the last five years. She employs four people from her community and they work from 6AM to 3PM every day except Sunday.

Belancille is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more foodstuffs to sell to her customers.  With this loan, Belancille hopes to improve service to her customers by providing reliable supply and timely delivery of Irish potatoes.  With this strategy, she hopes to realize more profit to reinvest in her business and improve her family’s livelihood.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs like Irish potatoes for resale

loans.name: Ngone

texts.fr:
Madame Ngone S. habite à Ouakam. Elle a 33 ans. Elle est marie et mère  d’un enfant .Madame  S.   était  quelques années avant enfant bénéficiaire du programme de développement  de l’enfant et de la famille  (PDEF) de Ouakam. Ses deux principales activités  sont le commerce et la couture. C’est par le biais de sa mère  qui faisait en mémé  temps le commerce et la teinture que Ngone  s’est créé une place dans le commerce après l’arrêt  des activités  de cette dernière. Ce  qui lui plait le plus c’est    le contact avec la clientèle, les voyages qu’elle effectue dans la sous région et les échanges d’expérience. Elle capitalise une expérience de 13 ans dans son activité. Elle sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs dans le but d’acheter des tissus, les coudre et les vendre. Pour elle le crédit lui permet de réalisera des Progrès et d’être indépendante financièrement. Grâce a ses bénéfices elle parvient à supporter ses besoins personnels ainsi que ceux de son fils.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  a exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique apprécié
texts.en:
Ms. Ngone S. lives in Ouakam.  She is 33 years old, married, and the mother of one child.  A few years before, she was a recipient parent of the Ouakam PDEF (programme de développement  de l’enfant et de la famille), a development program for children and families.  With funds from her mother, who at the time used to work in the cloth dyeing business, Ngone established a place in the business after her mother halted her work in it. What she likes the most is the customer contact, the trips she makes in the region, and trading experiences.  She capitalizes on thirteen years of experience in this business. Ngone is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs with the goal of buy some fabrics to sew and to sell.  In her case, loans allow her to make progress and to be financially independent.  Thanks to her profits, she is able to cover her personal needs, as well as her son's. Continuing in its aim of participating actively in the struggle against poverty, U-IMCEC is succeeding with positive backing from lenders to support the people in operating their profitable revenue-generating businesses, which facilitate valued socio-economic development.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Augmenting her working capital

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: Maria Luisa tiene 54 años de edad, es divorciada hace varios años y vive con su hijo de 16 años, vive en casa propia. Su hijo salió bachiller recientemente. Maria Luisa se dedica a la comercialización de prendas de vestir generalmente para damas, no tiene puesto fijo pero si tiene buena clientela en las instituciones donde entrega su mercadería, se dedica a esta actividad desde hace muchos años. Maria Luisa tiene competencia en su rubro pero debido a su experiencia ella tiene mercado asegurado, tiene bastantes amistades las cuales les recomiendan a más clientes por la calidad de prendas que ella vende. Maria Luisa en esta oportunidad traerá ropa de otra ciudad, ya que en la temporada de verano tendrá mucho pedido, por otra parte tendrá gastos de consumo. Maria Luisa trabaja también con otra entidad financiera desde hace tiempo. Es muy buena cliente en nuestra institución y no tiene malos antecedentes crediticios.
texts.en:
Maria Luisa is 54 years old and has been divorced for many years. She lives with her sixteen year old son in their own house. Her son recently received his high school diploma. Maria Luisa sells clothes, primarily for women. She doesn’t have her own store but she has good customer base in the institutions where she delivers her merchandise. She has been doing this business for many years. Maria is a competent businesswoman with a steadfast clientele. She has many friends that recommend her to other customers because she sells good quality clothes. Maria Luisa has an opportunity to bring her clothes to another city that has a lot of business during the summer months. If she does this she will have additional costs. Maria Luisa has worked with another financial entity for a long time. She is a good customer in our institution and has a good credit record

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expenses

loans.name: Paz Melly

texts.en:
Paz Melly M. is a 50-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Tapi, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by being a candy manufacturer.

Paz’s husband, Florentino, works as a farmer but sometimes helps out in his wife's business. They have four adult children aged between 20 and 30 with one currently going to school and they also help out in the business as part of their daily chores.

Paz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in candy manufacturing. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 32,000 from her business activities.

Paz is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 29,500 was used to fund the operations of her candy manufacturing and had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Borrowing the amount of PHP 29,500 for her 17th loan, she intends to use the money on her candy manufacturing. Paz is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. Paz is with her husband in the picture.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 47-year-old married man and has one child. He has been working as a carpenter and furniture builder since 1984. He has always worked out of his home where he has prepared a special room for this purpose. And over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his family's needs. 

After this long experience in this occupation, Bilal is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to open a carpentry shop and make the needed preparations in order to develop his business by taking more orders from the clients and making more profit.

loans.use: open a carpentry shop

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.es: Esta joven es maestra de escuela primaria tiene 41 de edad es madre soltera, tiene un hijo a su cargo el cual es menor de edad, ella es maestra de computación en la escuela Ricardo Morales Avilés en el municipio de Posoltega de donde es originaria, ella está trabajando con nuestra institución desde el año 2006, los créditos que se le han otorgado han sido para mejorar su vivienda y este último que se le está otorgando es para solventar  el pago del título de su carrera.
texts.en:
This young woman is a primary school teacher, 41 years old, and a single mother with a child who is a minor in her charge. She teaches computation at the Ricardo Morales Avilés School in the municipality of Posoltega where she comes from. Reyna has been working with our institution since 2006. The loans she has received have been for improvements to her house and this latest loan we have agreed to is for paying the fee required for receiving her professional degree.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PAYING THE FEE FOR HER UNIVERSITY DEGREE

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita T. is a 48-year-old widow who supports her family by running a general store and restaurant or eatery business. She lives in Brgy. Prosperidad, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental with her two married children (who are 23 and 24 years old) and her two grandchildren.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and restaurant businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 19,600.

Carmelita is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she could continue to sustain her general store and restaurant. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Carmelita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Batbayar is 20 years old and lives with his parents and sibling in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They have been living together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, for 15 years. Batbayar is a meat preparer and cutter at Huchit Shonhor, the biggest food wholesaling market in Mongolia, where he has been working since 2004. With his earnings, he purchased his own car in 2008. Furthermore, he has been planning to open a counter of his own for a meat selling business at the Huchit Shonhor market.

Batbayar has been working hard to improve his family's quality of life. He is a very hardworking person and is focused on the future. Batbayar's sibling is in his first year at university. Batbayar is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~ 750 USD) loan to pay his sibling's university tuition fee.

loans.use: To pay his sibling's university tuition fee

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria R. is from the village of San Isidro, Talakag Bukidnon. She is 41 years old and married with seven school-aged children. To make a living, Victoria runs a sari-sari (variety) shop selling both food and daily use products. Victoria has been engaged in her business for several years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Victoria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Laïdou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Laïdou est constitué des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 24 ans et de 2 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales nucléaires avec leurs enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le quartier Hérémakono-Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Par des relations d’amitiés et de commerce, ces femmes se sont connues et font le commerce de  fruits et légumes : banane plantain, noix de coco, ananas (à l’image de Kadia Samaké) et  de la restauration. 
Pour améliorer leurs capacités d’achats afin et de faire assez de stock, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui elles sont à leur troisième  prêt de groupe et tous les  prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Madame Kadia Samaké fait le commerce de fruits et légumes tels  les bananes plantains, les ananas et les noix de coco à côté de son mari qui est un soudeur installé au cœur de la ville de Bougouni au abords  de la route nationale N°7 qui relie Abidjan (république de Côte d’Ivoire) à Bamako (république du Mali).
Kadia Samaké compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50 régimes de bananes plantain, 200kg d’ananas, 100kg de noix de cocos. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des chauffeurs de camions qui font escale à Bougouni lors de leur passage d’Abidjan pour Bamako. Toutes les ventes se font en détail, au comptant et à crédit dans la ville de Bougouni, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt le elle espère obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de  35000 FCFA alors que les autres membres du groupe comptent sur un bénéfice mensuel de 25000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans l’entretien des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Laïdou is composed of married women averaging 24 years of age and two children. They live in nuclear conjugal families with their children and husband. These women reside in the Hérémakono-Nord district of Bougouni City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of friendship and commerce, and their businesses involve fruit and vegetables: plantains, coconuts, pineapples (as with Kadia Samaké), and food catering. To improve their buying power in order to build up a large enough stock, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third group loan. All the preceding ones were repaid. Ms. Kadia Samaké does commerce in fruit and vegetables, such as plantains, pineapple, and coconuts next to her husband, who is a welder. Her business is situated in the heart of Bougouni City along the National Road No. 7, which links Abidjan (Republic of Cote d’Ivoire) and Bamako (Republic of Mali). Kadia plans on using her loan to buy 50 bunches of plantains, 200 kg of pineapples, and 100 kg of coconuts. She gets her supplies from truck drivers who stop over in Bougouni on their way from Bamako to Abidjan. All sales are cash or credit retail sales to a customer base composed of women and men in Bougouni City. With this loan, Kadia hopes to have a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA, while the other group members plan on a monthly profit of 25,000 francs. The profit will be used for taking care of the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fruit

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion A., 55, ensures that her family members can fulfill their daily needs. She is married to Reynaldo A., an overseas Filipino worker, and the couple is blessed with four children. Asuncion helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She manages a variety store while offering a mini-catering service. She also has an electronic cellular phone loading station where she sells load to different networks.

Asuncion has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year.  She regularly attends weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has borrowed several times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, Asuncion would like to apply for a PHP 26,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to replenish the stock of her current product inventory. She also will invest some of the loan in buying cellular phone load for different networks.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To replenish current inventory

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is the wife of M. Y. and lives in Lahore, a city in Pakistan which is famous for historical sites. She and her husband, who makes his living as a blacksmith by making items such as doors and window frames on order, have five children. Razia has applied for a loan to invest her husband’s business by purchasing the supplies of iron he needs to make his products. She hopes that this loan will help her husband increase his  income and improve the family's finances. 

Razia also leads a loan group with five other members, each of whom will use her portion of this loan to improve or expand a small family businesses.

loans.use: To buy iron to use in manufacturing items for sale

loans.name: Delight Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Charcoal is obtained from burning a piece of fresh timber in the absence of oxygen. It is one of the most common sources of energy for cooking in every traditional home. It is also the most affordable. Selling charcoal is a lucrative business for women like Hagar. She purchases bags of charcoal and has been retailing it to customers in her community for the past six years. She also sells groceries, soft drinks, and sachet water. She plans to invest the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal and fill the demand for her groceries, soft drinks, and sachet water. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Hagar is divorced and she is the mother of four children from age 11-21 years. She describes herself as hard-working. She dreams of being able to open a branch of her grocery store and purchase stock in bulk to minimize frequent travel and risks. Hagar believes in education and hopes to support her children to attain better education.

Hagar is also the group leader of 'Delight Trust Bank Group' made up of seven members. The other members of her group sell foodstuffs, smoked fish, rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal, groceries, soft drinks and sachet water

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina R. is from the village of Asinng-via, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 37 years old. Gina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing waste management services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from owning a tricycle transport service. Gina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair the existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Gina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support the immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair the existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie B. is from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Virgie is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Virgie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Virgie has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virgie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Virgie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa, de 35 años, vive en su casa que es propia, en compañía de su esposo Olo de 48 años, y de sus 2 jóvenes hijos, juntos habitan en un paraje de la apacible serranía peruana. Desde muy joven se dedica a las labores agrícolas, antes ayudaba a sus padres y hoy trabaja las tierras junto a su esposo. Siembra papa, arveja y maíz en sus chacras propias, y le gusta despertarse muy temprano para vigilar sus campos, pues sabe que de su esfuerzo constante depende que obtenga un productiva cosecha que venderá a buenos precios a los mayoristas de la ciudad. Luego de la cosecha comercializa todos sus productos naturales, pues sus compradores conocen de la calidad de su producción. Pero siempre trabaja pensando en sacar adelante a sus hijos, pues quiere que estudien una carrera y sean profesionales, además dice que lo más trabajoso es trasladar toda su producción para comercializarla, ya que los sacos son bastante pesados. Como es una mujer emprendedora para mas adelante tiene planeado sembrar en mayor cantidad, para generarse mejores ingresos. Es el séptimo crédito con MFP y esta muy agradecida con todas las personas que hicieron posible el crédito que le permitirá continuar trabajando, también esta muy satisfecho con el trabajo de su grupo comunal porque son personas organizadas y responsables en el pago de sus cuotas. Rosa tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de 3 sacos de abono y semilla de arveja, pues desea mejorar la productividad de sus campos, de esta manera espera continuar progresando.
texts.en:
Rosa, 35 years old, lives in her own home along with her husband Olo, 48 years old, and two young children. They all live together on a trail along the pleasant Peruvian hill country. She has been working in agriculture since she was young. First she helped her parents, now she works the land with her husband. They plant potatoes, peas and corn on their own farm. She enjoys waking up early to tend to her fields because she knows her hard work is necessary to obtain a productive crop to sell to the whole sellers in town. She sells her production as soon as she harvests it because her buyers know the quality of her products. She always works thinking of improving her children's lives. She wants them to go to school and become professionals. In addition, she says the hardest part of her job is transporting her production to sell it since the bags are very heavy. Being the entrepreneur that she is, she plans to plant more to generate more income. This is her seventh credit with MFP. She is very thankful for all people who have made the loan that will help her continue to work possible. She is also very pleased with the work of her community group. They are well organized and responsible for the payment of their loans. Rosa plans to invest their loan in the purchase of three bags of fertilizer and pea seeds. She wants to improve her field's productivity and therefore continue to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three bags of fertilizer and pea seeds

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben is a 27-year-old married man who belongs to Mwiki Dreamers group in Faulu Kenya.

Reuben runs a taxi business and hopes to invest in his business through his savings so as to improve his standard of living. In ten years, he wants to buy a new taxi.

He is requesting 20,000 KES to buy spare parts for his vehicle. He describes himself as a hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Carlos Alfredo

texts.es: Carlos Alfredo G. tiene 20 años de edad, reside en el Barrio Palmira del Municipio de San Esteban junto a su compañera de hogar y sus dos hijos de 2 y 7 años de edad. Es un joven trabajador y cuenta con muy buenas referencias por parte de sus vecinos. Inició a trabajar desde los 12 años de edad porque sus padres no pudieron darle la oportunidad de estudiar. Carlos actualmente comercializa todo tipo de accesorios para celular, películas y lentes para el sol, los vende a diario de forma ambulante recorriendo a pie grandes distancias. El préstamo lo necesita para comprar cargadores, cobertores y películas y así surtir su negocio de nuevos y novedosos productos. Uno de los desafíos que enfrenta es que se requiere de mucho esfuerzo físico y que en esta temporada del año las lluvias son muy frecuentes y tiene que tener mucho cuidado con la mercancía porque si se le moja se le arruina. Su sueño es establecer su negocio en un local y llegar a ser un distribuidor autorizado de una compañía de telefonía celular para obtener mayores ganancias y así poder construir su casa propia.
texts.en:
Carlos Alfredo G. is 20 years old, and resides in the Palmira neighborhood of the town of San Esteban, together with his live-in partner and their two children of 2 and 7. He is a hard-working young man, and is well-regarded by his neighbors. He began working at the age of 12 because his parents could not afford to send him to school. Presently, Carlos sells all kinds of accessories for cell phones, as well as movies and sunglasses. He sells them every day on foot, traveling large distances. He needs the loan to buy chargers, covers, and movies and thus supply his business with new and novel products. One of the difficulties he faces is that his job requires a lot of physical effort and that in this season it rains frequently, and he has to be very careful with his merchandise, because if it gets wet it is ruined. His dream is to set up his business in one place and become an authorized distributor for a cell phone company, so he can earn more and thus be able to build his own house.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Powell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar accesorios para telefonos celulares

loans.name: Arely Sugey

texts.es:
La Joven Arely Sugey Chavarría P., se dedica a vender sopa y nacatamales, es madre soltera de un niño de 2 añitos, trabaja por cuenta propia.

Lleva ya 36 créditos con ceprodel los cuales los utiliza para compra de insumos para la preparación de sus ventas, ha demostrado ser una persona muy responsable en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Arely Sugey Chavarría P. sells soup and nacatamales (Nicaraguan tamales popular as weekend fare).  She is a single mother of a 2-year-old son.  She works on her own initiative.

She has had 36 Ceprodel loans that she has used to buy ingredients to prepare the food she sells.

She has shown herself to be a very responsible person with respect to her repayments.

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida T. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 28 years old. Aida is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Virginia Wairimu

texts.en:
Virginia Wairimu aged 31 is a single mother of one child aged 14 years and in primary school. Virginia runs a green grocery shop where she sells tomatoes, bananas, oranges, onions and potatoes among other things in the Lunga Lunga area which is in a slum district.

Virginia has been running this green grocery shop for a period of eight years and she gets a monthly income of Kshs 8,000. Her customers are satisfied and they refer their friends to her green grocery for her quality goods which are sold at fair prices.

With the loan Virginia intends to buy onions, tomatoes, potatoes, oranges, and bananas to sell and with the extra income generated she will increase the stock of other groceries to maximize profit.

Virginia’s dream is to be able to supply her groceries wholesale which will give her more profit. This will enable her to improve the living standards of her children and give them quality education. She also wants to move her green grocery from the open air place to a shop.

Virginia is a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, bananas, oranges, onions, and potatoes for resale

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay T., 35, has been working as a policeman since 2005, and has a proper salary very month. (Lay T. was not available the day of the photo, so his wife is in the photo instead.) Lay T. can earn a living by working this position for approximately of $6.50 per day. He has a life partner in his wife, who is a garment worker. The couple has three children; all of them are single and living under their roof. Currently, Lay T. wishes to open a new business selling breakfast and coffee  in front their house in order to make more income to ensure their family living is a comfortable life. But his account savings is not enough to make that possible. So, he would request a loan to open a coffee and breakfast shop for additional profit.

loans.use: To open coffee shop and selling breakfast for additional profit.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a single woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for basic needs for her mother, rent bills and electricity bills. 

She has operated a cosmetic shop for the past three years; her customers are neighbors and passersby. In addition, she operates M-pesa (mobile money transfer service). Susan faces a major challenge of competition in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase hair, food, oil and cosmetics for her cosmetic shop. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her cosmetic shop.

loans.name: Siyatotoba Group

texts.en:
Nkosikhona is 21 years old and single with one child, age 2. She runs a public phone shop in Empangeni, South Africa. She's been in this business for a year, selling airtime on public phones from her shop. She also earns income from a government child support grant. She says that the main challenges to her business are electrical problems that cause her to close her shop. 

She requested this loan from WDB and Kiva to buy airtime for her public phones. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her be able to buy furniture. She would like to grow her business and expand with a beauty store.

Nkosikhona is the leader of her borrower group and is on the far left in the photo above.

loans.use: To purchase airtime for public phones

loans.name: Abad Al Motleb

texts.en:
Abad Al Motleb is a 28 year old married man who is the father of two kids.  They live in Baalbeck. Abad Al Motleb and he has been working as a car mechanic since 2008.  He is requesting his first loan from Al Majmoua, in order to improve his business.  He was out of Lebanon for a long period and came back in 2008 with his family for good. 

He was dreaming of opening a big maintenance company but the financial situation in Lebanon isn’t good, and he has to stay up to date to maintain his family's standard of living. He hopes to educate his children in a good private schools and to provide them with the things they need.  He will struggle to make his dream come true and he believes that where there’s a will there’s a way

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Teodosia

texts.es: Teodosia, de 47 años, siempre ha trabajado muy duro por sobresalir en la vida, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo Pedro (42), quien trabaja como albañil, y sus tres pequeños  hijos, quienes son el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos.En la comunidad de Yurinaki, se encuentra el negocio de Teodosia, su puesto esta ubicado en la plaza de la comunidad, en donde vende gallinas, patos y gansos, los cuales están bien alimentados y cuidados, es por eso que tiene muchos clientes y sus ingresos económicos son buenos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo, es alimentar a sus aves, ya que los cría con mucho cariño, lleva seis  años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil, es tener que permanecer en su puesto todo el día en espera de clientes. Para el futuro, planea alquilar una tienda donde pueda brindar a sus clientes una mejor comodidad a la hora de atenderlos.Este es el sétimo préstamo de Teodosia con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar puntualmente sus cuotas y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es una socia muy alegre y responsable.Con los quinientos soles solicitados, comprará más alimento para sus aves, ya que tienen que estar grandes y sanos para comercializarlos a mejores precios.
texts.en:
Teodosia is 47 years old and has always worked very hard to get ahead in life.  She lives in her own home together with her husband Pedro (42), who works as a construction worker, and her three young children who are the motivation behind all her hard work.

Teodosia's business is located in the community of Yurinaki.  Her sales stall is located in the community square where she sells chickens, ducks and geese which are well fed and cared for.  For this reason, she has a lot of customers and her income is good.  What she most likes about her work is feeding her birds since she raises them with a lot of care.  She has been in this business for six years and she considers the most difficult part of her work to be having to remain on her stall all day waiting for customers.  In the future, she plans to hire a store where she can serve her customers more comfortably.

This is Teodosia's seventh loan with MFP.  She knows that she must make her repayments on time and she is ready to do so.  She is a very happy and responsible member of her community bank.  She will use the 500 Peruvian soles she has requested to buy more feed for her birds since they have to grow big and healthy if she is to sell them for a better price.

loans.use: To buy feed to fatten her animals

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is married and has three children. She sells food supplies like 'gari' (quick-cooking cassava grits) and maize for sale at Elmina. Her husband is a farmer. Ama uses her income to assist her husband with the general upkeep of the home.

 Ama will use the loan to purchase more sacks of 'gari' and maize for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to re-invest into the food selling business.

loans.use: purchase more sacks of 'gari' and maize for resale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENKADI est constitué de 7  mariées et 3 veuves ayant une moyenne d’âge de 46  ans et  5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à BOUGOULABA un des villages de la sous préfecture de NIENA  région de Sikasso (3e région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été remboursés dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels le beurre de karité  avec KOROTOUMOU D.. 
KOROTOUMOU D.  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 50kg de beurre de karité.  Elle s’approvisionne au marché de BOUGOULABA. Le beurre est  revendu au  marché de de BOUGOULABA et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant et en détail. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA utilise  pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille .
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of ten members; 7 are married women and three are widows. They are all around 46 years old and have six children each. They generally live in polygamous families in Bougoulaba, a village in the Niena municipality in the Sikasso region (the third largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They are on their third loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance association, with the aim of better satisfying their customers' demands. They have successfully repaid all of their previous loans. These ladies are led by group leader Korotoumou D. and sell various products, such as shea butter. Korotoumou D. aims to use her loan to purchase 50kg of shea butter which she will source from the Bougoulaba market. She re-sells this butter by retail or wholesale at the Bougoulaba market, to her family members, and to a customer base made up of women and men. 
She aims to generate an average monthly wage of 40,000 FCFA which she will use to meet her family's everyday needs. She aims to boost her revenue in order to better meet her customers' demands.

loans.use: Purchasing shea butter

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
From the province of Kompong Tom, Sor M. is 31 years old, married and the mother of one young child, who is enrolled in a local school. She is a local farmer who grows rice crops to earn a living. Sor M.'s husband works as a construction foreman in the village. 

The family usually generates a profit of approximately $7 USD each day to help support the whole family. In the past, they had lived with their parents and now their new house is in the building process. As they face a problem with financial factors, their new house is not finished. In order to deal with this issue, Sor M. has decided to borrow some funds from Kiva to complete building her new house. 

Sor M. and her young son are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To complete building her new home

loans.name: Rosita Jorgina

texts.es: La señora Rosita Jorgina V. C. , tiene la edad de 39 años , habita en el municipio de la Concepción , junto a su esposo el cual labora como albañil , para apoyarla con los gastos de hogar , ellos  tienen tres hijos  los cuales estudian y le apoyan con el negocio , doña Rosita desde hace   16 años se dedica a la venta de ropa , zapatos , cosméticos entre otras actividades para poder darle un mejor bienestar a sus hijos , los planes  hacia un futuro es poder verlos realizados con unos profesionales y no pasen todas las necesidades por las  cuales se ha enfrentado para poder darle el alimento de cada día ,la señora con el primer crédito amplio su negocio ya que ella ahora tiene hasta un pequeño salón de belleza para obtener más ingresos  , agradece el apoyo que le brinda Afodenic atrávez de los fondo Kiva ya que ah mejorado su condición de vida , ahora quiere este segundo ciclo para invertirlo en comprar de ropa y zapato.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosita Jorgina V. C. is 39 years old and lives in the town of Concepción. She and her husband, who works as a mason, support one another with the household expenses. They have three children in school who help her with her business. For the past sixteen years, Doña Rosita has been selling clothes, shoes, and cosmetics to provide for her children’s welfare. Her plans for the future include seeing them become professionals. There is not a day that goes by in which she tries to meet the daily needs of her children.

With her first loan, Sra. Rosita expanded her business and now she has a small beauty salon that helps her generate more income. She is grateful for the support AFODENIC has provided with the Kiva funds so that she could improve her living conditions. Now that she is in her second loan cycle, Rosita wants to invest in the purchase of clothing and shoes.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina lives in Mian Channu, a small city in Punjab, Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a three-room brick house with her family in the Meharbad area for the past five years. She is a housewife, staying at home to do her household responsibilities. She is a very good mother who has raised her four children very well. Her eldest son sells wheat and rice and the second works in a factory. The remaining two children stay at home and are unemployed. Robina couldn’t provide them with an education due to poor financial conditions.

Her husband, Y. M., has a grocery store in the market. Robina helps her husband by visiting his grocery store once a day to deal with his customers. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband to stock more groceries in order to fulfill his customer demands. He has been running this business for the past five years and Robina hopes that with the loan investment her husband’s business will grow further and his monthly income will be increased.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Robina.

loans.use: to buy groceries for a grocery store business.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophat Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 11 members. Mrs. Sophat is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family's standard of living.
Mrs. Sophat is a mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer while the others study at the local public school. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she grows rice for her own family and to sell. Her husband, Mr. Norb, owns some cinema equipment that he rents out to earn some money to support his family. Since her husband’s business is getting on well, Mrs. Sophat wants to expand it. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to buy more cinema equipment.

loans.use: to buy more cinema equipment

loans.name: La Esperanza Del Futuro Group

texts.es:
La señora Beroisa Sánchez Alegría, vive en la Ribera Benito Juárez Municipio de Copainala Estado de Chiapas México, ella  es casada y tiene  cuatro hijos a su responsabilidad quienes son: Blanca Dareni, Nemias, Jerson, Dania Esmeralda y Margot.
 
       El préstamo solicitado lo invirtió en la compra de  ingredientes como son: harina, aceite, queso, huevo, entre otros para la elaboración de panes, en donde nos comenta que lleva  cuatro años y le va bien ya que con ellos está logrando sacar adelante sus hijos.

      Se dedica a esta actividad ya que cuando era joven apoyaba a una señora que fue su vecina la enseño a elaborarlo y  años  después lo continuo  a practicarlo, así lograr tener ingresos para  solventar sus ingresos de su familia.
 
      Lo que más desea es que su actividad aumente para  ahorrar y seguir apoyando a sus hijos y  nietos que están estudaindo.
 
      las personas  que integarn en este grupo son las eñora Martha quien se dedica a la elaboración de quesos y la señora Maria Deysi quien se dedicará a vender  pollos y marranos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Beroisa Sánchez Alegría lives in Ribera Benito Juárez in Copainala, a municipality in the Mexican State of Chiapas.  She’s married and has four children in her care.  They are: Blanca Dareni, Nemias, Dania Esmeralda and Margot.

She used the requested loan to buy ingredients like: flour, oil, cheese and eggs, among others, to make bread.  She comments that she’s been in business for four years and does well because she’s able to support her children this way.

She is in this line of work because as a youngster she helped a neighbor lady who taught her how to make it and then she continued to practice.  She is now able to earn income this way to meet family expenses.  What she most wants is that her business grows to save up and continue to support her children and grandchildren who are in school.

The people who make up this group are: Martha, who is a cheese maker and María Deysi who will sell chickens and pigs.

loans.use: to buy bread baking ingredients.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca nació en el distrito de Taray provincia de Calca del departamento del Cusco (Taray se encuentra a 45 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco), ella tiene 48 años edad y tiene cuatro hijos. Actualmente, ella vive en la ciudad del Cusco. (La ciudad de Taray caracteriza por tener hermosos paisajes por ser una zona ganadera y agrícola). 

Francisca y su esposo Agustín tienen una pequeña empresa de fabricación de muebles de madera, Agustin es quien fabrica los muebles de madera y Francisca hace los acabados del muebles y también ayudan los hijos pues ahora se convirtió en un negocio familiar. Francisca es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora que también se dedica a la venta de artesanía en el Mirador de Taray que está ubicado a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Taray, ella sale a trabajar de desde las 9 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde todos los días. (El Mirador de Taray es el primer lugar donde se puede realmente apreciar la belleza del Valle Sagrado.)

Francisca vende artesanía de tipo cerámica y ropa. Ya son 15 años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien. En esta oportunidad Francisca requiere el préstamo para comprar materiales para la fabricación de muebles como por ejemplo madera, laca y otras cosas más. Ella también desea comprar mercadería para el negocio de la artesania como por ejemplo ropa, mochilas, sombreros, etc.

Francisca pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de la Agonía de Taray” de la Asociación Arariwa. El banco comunal esta en el cuarto y medio de año de funcionamiento y les va muy bien.
texts.en:
Francisca was born in Taray district, in Calca province, in Cusco department. (Taray is located 45 minutes from the city of Cusco).  Francisca is 48 years old and has four children.  She currently lives in the city of Cusco. (The city of Taray is noted for its beautiful landscape and the fact that its residents work in agriculture and livestock raising).

Francisca and her husband Agustín have a small company that makes wooden furniture.  Agustín is the one who makes the wooden furniture and Francisca puts the finishing touches to them.  Their children also help out and it has become a family business.  Francisca is a hard-working and enterprising woman who also sells handicrafts in El Mirador de Taray which is located 10 minutes from the city of Taray.  She goes out to work from 9.00am to 4.00pm every day (El Mirador de Taray is the first place from which you can really appreciate the beauty of the Sacred Valley).

The handicrafts that Francisca sells are ceramics and clothes.  She has been in this business for 15 years and it is doing very well.  On this occasion, Francisca needs a loan to buy materials for making furniture such as wood, lacquer, etc.  She would also like to buy merchandise for her handicrafts business such as clothes, backpacks, hats, etc.

Francisco is a member of Asociación Arariwa's “Señor de la Agonía de Taray” community bank which has been going for four and a half years and is doing very well.

loans.use: to buy materials for making furniture and merchandise for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Gem Yalla Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 10 juillet 2002. Il est composé de 06 femmes qui habitent dans le même quartier.

Madame FATOU qui est à gauche de la photo levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 46 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Elle a aussi en charge quatre autres enfants de ses frères.

Elle mène l'activité de vente et d'achat de divers produits (balais, huile de palme, légumes etc) dans les marché de la ville. Elle capitalise une bonne expérience dans ce domaine pour l'avoir pratiquée depuis plus de cinq.

Ce prêt lui permettra de financer son activité de petit commerce de balais, d'huile de palme, de légumes etc..

Son objectif est d'appuyer son mari dans l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
The solidarity group was created on July 10, 2002 and is made up of six women who live in the same neighborhood.

Madame Fatou (raising her hand on the left) is the leader of the group. She is 46 years old, married, and the mother of two children. She also takes care of four nephews. She buys and sells various products (brooms, palm oil, vegetables, etc.) at the city market. She has more than five years' experience in this business. 

This loan will allow her to finance her business selling brooms, palm oil, vegetables, etc. Her goal is to help her husband improve the family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy brooms, palm oil, vegetables and other items.

loans.name: María Dioselina

texts.es:
En el sector conocido como la calle 26 De Septiembre en la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Los Nardos.

La señora María es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque los intereses son más bajos que en otras instituciones de crédito. Tiene 24 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 3 y de 1 año ocho meses. Su esposo es Ing. En sistemas.

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo de muchas marcas nacionales y extranjeras. Además de productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres días a la semana más que todo por las noches ya que a esa hora ya tiene  con quien dejar a sus pequeños hijos, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana o cada quince de acuerdo a lo que quieran sus clientes. Los productos Yanbal  los recibe en su casa y lo que es ropa en el centro en una distribuidora. Lleva 5 meses  que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien a pesar del poco tiempo, nos cuenta que empezó este negocio con uno de los créditos que recibió de la institución, antes se dedicaba a otro tipo de negocios pero no le fue muy bien por eso cambio y ahora le va mejor.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y ropa de todo tipo.
 
Su sueño es tener casa propia ya que donde vive es alquilado.

En la foto nuestra socia está con su pequeña hija.
texts.en:
In the sector known as 26th of September Street in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabi, known for many years as the city of the royal tamarinds, the members of the “Los Nardos” (The Spikenards) Communal Bank meet every 15 days.

Maria is a founding member of this communal bank and she likes it because the interest rates are lower than in other credit institutions.  She is 24 years of age, married, and from this union has come 2 children aged 3 and 1 year 8 months. Her husband is a systems engineer. 

Maria is a housewife who, to obtain her own resources, dedicates herself to selling clothing from a catalog containing many national and foreign brands. In addition, she sells Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes, and accessories for ladies). Maria works 3 days a week, plus every night, when during these hours she has someone to leave the children with. She sells her products on credit and collects each week or every 15 days, according to her customer's preferences. Maria receives the Yanbal products at home, and the clothing in the center at a distributorship. She has been doing this for 5 months and it is going very well, despite the short time. Maria tells us that she began this business with one of the loans she received from our institution. Before that, she was tried a different type of business but it didn't go well, and so she made the change and, now, business is much better.

This loan is for buying perfumes, creams, cosmetics, and clothing of all types.

Her dream is to have her own house, since where she lives now is rented.

In our picture, Maria appears with her little daughter.

loans.use: buy perfumes, creams, cosmetics, and clothing to sell.

loans.name: Jemalyn

texts.en:
Jemalyn is 21 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single. 

Jemalyn has a shop that sells snacks, beverages & canned goods. She has had this business for 2 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Jemalyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2007. In the future, Jemalyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en: Carmen is a married parent of six children who works hard to support her family. She has a fish-vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a sari-sari (variety) store. Carmen is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to buy additional fish to sell. She has sustained her business activities through her past 7 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy additional fish to sell

loans.name: Qorkhmaz

texts.en:
Qorkhmaz, age 41, is a market vendor. He has been selling fruit for 12 years, during which time he has acquired the knowledge and skills required for making the business a success. For instance, he knows how to store the fruits so as to keep their marketable conditions so as not to lose their taste and other desirable properties. 

He sells items like apples, peaches, and pomegranates in the local central market, but now, in summer, he mostly sells watermelon and other melons, the most popular summer fruits among local people. In the market he is known for his attractive prices and his friendliness. This allows Qorkhmaz’s business to generate a considerable stable income for his family. Qorkhmaz is married and has four children. 
 
He is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN, which will allow him to purchase more fruits to offer for sale. He is confident that this will allow him to increase his profit and expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits to offer for sale

loans.name: Amparo Dicenia

texts.en: Amparo lives in Choluteca, Honduras, with her three children. For the past 15 years she has made a living by running a small general store. She is requesting a loan of 12,000 HNL to purchase merchandise for her store. In her free time, Amparo enjoys attending church.

loans.use: to purchase snacks, candy, soft drinks, beans, rice, eggs, lard, cooking oil, household cleaning supplies, and personal hygiene products.

loans.name: Kusile 2 Red Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe!  Edward  is 74 years old and comes from Gweru. He is married with nine children. He also cares for one dependent.

 Edward runs a retail business selling cement and maize. The business has been in operation for two years. He says the main challenges faced are transport to the rural areas, slow turnover and high purchasing costs.

 Edward has requested a loan of $400 to buy more cement and maize. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow him to have more disposable income and therefore a better quality of life. In the future Edward plans to own a bigger shop and employ staff.

loans.use: to buy cement and maize for the store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timber and firewood.

loans.name: Glenda Rosibel

texts.es:
Glenda, vive con su esposo y una hija de 3 años de edad, ella es ama de casa, dedicada a los quehaceres de la cocina, su esposo es agricultor, siembra maíz, trabaja todos los días de la semana.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de abono y semilla, porque su esposo realizara la siembra y ella le apoyara con el préstamo, aunque su pago lo harán de la cosecha que reciban.
Ella tiene el sueño, de algún día trabajando junto a su esposo puedan construirse su propia casa, ya que actualmente viven con la familia de él.
texts.en:
Glenda lives with her husband and 3 year old daughter. She is a housewife, devoted to her kitchen chores. Her husband is a farmer who plants corn and works every day of the week. 

She is asking for a loan to buy manure and seeds becasue her husband takes care of the sowing and she supports him with the loan, although the repayment will be made from the harvest they obtain. She dreams of one day working alongside her husband to build their own house as they currently live with her husband's family.

loans.use: to buy manure and seeds for sowing.

loans.name: Omurgul's Group

texts.en:
Omurgul is the treasurer of this group. She is 29 and, together with her husband, she brings up four sons. The two older sons study at school and the other sons are of preschool age. Her husband earns money by transporting passengers and Omurgul sells dairy products. She started this business nine years ago with an initial investment of 17000 soms. Currently her monthly profit is 12000 soms. With the profits, Omurgul has built a sauna and a kiosk. With the loan she wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
