This loan will be used to grow their businesses so they can better serve their customers, by increasing their merchandise and using better equipment. The members have a lot of experience and most of them have worked with similar groups, so they know how to manage the funds so that they can grow their businesses and increase their earnings for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: operational capital

loans.name: Quyên's Group

texts.en:
Quyên Lệ T. (ID 010110080003) was born in 1982. Currently, she lives in Văn Thượng village with her husband and two school-aged children. Since 2004, she has made a living by doing carpentry. This work generates an average monthly income of around 3,000,000 VND. In 2008, she joined Kiva partner, SEDA, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. Quyên repaid her first loan of 4,142,000 VND on time. This loan was used to expand her business. Now, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to invest in her business in the hope that it will make a profit and enable her family to buy more furniture.

About the other borrowers in her group
Hảo Thúy Thị Vương (ID 010110080002) is a 30-year-old female. She is requesting a loan of 6,322,000 VND to sell clothes.
Hà Thị Nguyễn (ID 010110080001) is 34 years old. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND to sell fruits.
Ái Thị Hà (ID 010110080005) is the eldest member of the group. She is a 40-year-old worker and wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND to buy pigs.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif G. is 46 years old. He is married and has three children. Sharif lives with his parents and is the main breadwinner for this large family. 

Sharif runs a café where he cooks different national dishes. A very good and experienced cook, Sharif managed to make his business successful. Sharif uses the income from his business to improve his family's living conditions. He also dreams about educating his children in the institutes and universities. 

Sharif is planning to make major repairs to his café so he can attract new clients and keep the old ones. For this purpose, he requests $2000 USD. Sharif thanks all lenders for their support and promises to be precise in his loan payments.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Major repairs to his café

loans.name: Ana Gabriel

texts.es:
La joven Ana Gabriel es madre soltera comerciante desde hace 3 años tiene su negocio quien con ayuda de sus padres con lo cual ha logrado salir adelante en su hogar y le ha permitido continuar con sus estudios universitarios y darle un mejor por venir a su hijo.
Este préstamo es para la compra de mercadería como arroz , azúcar , frijoles etc. lo cual le permitirá mejorar su negocio y así aumentar sus ganancias para el mejoramiento de su hogar
texts.en:
Miss Ana Gabriel is a single mother and businesswoman; for the past 3 years she's had her business that, with the help of her parents, has helped her to progress at home and allowed her to continue with her university studies and give her son a better future. This loan is for the purchase of merchandise, such as rice, sugar, beans, etc., that will allow her to improve her business and thus increase her profits in order to improve her home.

Translated from Spanish by Soraya Alamdari, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of consumer goods

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Chorn S. lives with his five children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He is a construction foreman who works all over the city, earning an income of $8 per day to help cover family expenses. He has been in this business since 1983 which has improved his standard of living. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy construction equipment. This is his first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: buy construction equipment

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok L. is 44 years old and sells fritters in the village. Her husband, Chou Somnang, 41, helps her in selling these products. This couple has helped each other in order to earn money to feed their children. Right now, two of their children are employed and provide their incomes to help with the responsibilities of the family, while the remaining two are students. Sok L. wants to enlarge her business, which is the main source of  income. Because Sok L. doesn’t have capital, she has decided to request a loan to be used to improve her store, as well as to buy more ingredients to produce the fritters that she sells.

loans.use: To improve her store as well as to buy more ingredients to produce fritters to sell.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda P. is from the village of Kalawaig, Banisilan Cotabato. She is 52 years old. Brenda is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Brenda owns & operates a business selling vegetables and a variety of fish in the local community. Brenda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Brenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Brenda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Brenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 37-year-old single man. He is living with one parent and one sibling. All three household members work to support the family’s expenses. He has owned his own bakery since 2008. He has to pay the “new” rent for his business, which is significantly more than that of long-time business owners, who have benefited from extremely low rent costs. 

This borrower is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to invest in two machines for his work. One will help in mixing the flour and water and the other will help roll out the dough and make it flat. In Lebanon, there are many small shops to buy fresh bread and homemade Lebanese “pizzas” called “manouche.” These foods are especially popular for breakfast or as a snack. 

This will be his second loan from Ameen. He demonstrated consistent and on-time payments during his last loan cycle.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To invest in two machines for his bakery work

loans.name: Ntara Multipurpose, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hardworking T. Patrick, aged 38 years, operates a certain vocational school in Ntara, Ibanda, where he is head teacher. This school started three years ago and has since been accessed by many students due to its set academic standards.

This loan will help Patrick in the purchase of furniture for the school like desks and chairs, so as to improve the standard of the school. He is very optimistic of making it grow into the best institution, not only in his region, but in Uganda.

Patrick belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan and this is the first time that Patrick is seeking a loan from Pearl.

Patrick is in a light blue shirt on the far right and is raising his hand. He is the one interviewed. The others with hands raised are committee members of the group.

loans.use: To buy furniture for his school

loans.name: Gasi

texts.en:
Gasi is a happily married man with four children: two are attending school while the others are still young. He owns a house with electricity but no piped water. He cites food as his greatest monthly expense. 

With the assistance of his wife, Gasi has been in business as a shopkeeper for the past twenty-four years. With the Kshs 20,000 loan, he wants to add stock (foodstuffs), neighbors and passersby being his potential customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future. His previous occupation was buying and selling livestock. He also operates a taxi as another source of income.

Gasi’s main challenge is the high statutory standards set by the local government. He joined Yehu because of its mission of empowering rural, social-economically-marginalized entrepreneurs through accessibility to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To add 50kgs of rice, 50kgs of sugar and 50kgs of beans to his store

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Moses S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Unity. He is 32 years old, married, and has two children, who are 13 months old and 8 years old. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial reasons.

For 6 years, he has been sewing garments and school uniforms in S.D. Cooper Community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his portion of this group loan (6,000 Liberian Dollars of the 30,000 Liberian Dollars total) to buy more cloth. He describes himself as a very committed person. His goal is to expand his business, build a house, and continue to educate his children so that they can have a promising future.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional cloth

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita E. is from the village of Poblacion, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Lolita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a member of Pamoja 45 group at Faulu Kenya. He operates Realtime Salon and Barber shop. Being in the business for fifteen years, he employs one person. He also runs a cereal shop and was previously employed as a driver. David, a father of two, works hard to provide for his family. He hopes to educate his children at the university level and also to build his own house in the future. As a member of a group in Faulu Kenya, he can easily access a loan. He has previously received one loan. He has requested another loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a shaving machine, sterilizer, seats, and mirrors. He describes himself as a hardworking and visionary man.

loans.use: To purchase a shaving machine, sterilizer, seats and mirrors

loans.name: El Arbol Group

texts.es:
El grupo solidario El Árbol se encuentra constituido por Lidia Marina Dávila Chavarría, Mayda R. P. y Auxiliadora del Socorro López. Lidia, quien es la coordinadora fabrica tortillas en su casa de habitación, así mismo vende frijoles cocidos, cabeza de chanco, buñuelos y nacatamales; ella inició hace 20 años solamente con las tortillas y poco a poco fue agregando más y más productos a su comercio.

Mayda también fabrica tortillas pero el único producto agregado que ella tiene es la venta de algunos derivados de los lácteos como el queso y la cuajada. Auxiliadora, vende nacatamales, pero así mismo ha agregado la venta de frescos, helados y choco banano, ella piensa invertir el crédito en nuevos giros como la fritanga.
texts.en:
The solidarity group “El Árbol” (The Tree) consists of Lidia Marina Dávila Chavarría, Mayda R. P., and Auxiliadora del Socorro López.

Lidia, who is the group coordinator, prepares tortillas at home. There she also sells baked beans, roasted pig’s head, fritters, and Nicaraguan tamales. She started her business 20 years ago selling only tortillas, but little by little, she added more products to sell.

Mayda also prepares tortillas, but the only other items that she sells are dairy products such as cheese and curds. Auxiliadora sells Nicaraguan tamales, but now she also sells soft drinks, ice cream, and frozen chocolate covered bananas. She plans to invest her loan in new products to sell, such as fried foods.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients & supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man and father of three school-age children. He lives in Lebanon. Since 1990 he has owned a shop where he sells fertilizers and organic products for agriculture. Situated in an agricultural area, his shop is well known by a good number of farmers who ask for his products.

Today, he wishes to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al. to increase his shop inventory. He wants to be prepared for the new season when all the farmers cultivate their lands for sowing.

loans.use: To increase his shop's inventory
